class="css-233int epjyd6m1"><p class="css-1xuzukf e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/eli-tan" class="last-byline css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" class="css-4q3lf8 epjyd6m0"><div id="enhanced-byline" class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-1hyokyd e1wtpvyy0">Reporting from Newton County, Ga.</p></div></div></div></div><ul class="css-1cgskve epjyd6m4"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m3"><time dateTime="2025-07-16T13:29:17-04:00" class="css-1gu861y e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->July 14, 2025</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->July 16, 2025</span></time></li></ul></div><div class="css-1h1tosb"><a class="css-3fkga7" href="https://www.nytimes.com/es/2025/07/15/espanol/negocios/centro-datos-meta-escasez-agua.html" data-version="es" title="Read in Spanish">Leer en español</a></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-ar1ez3"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-0"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">After <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/24/technology/meta-data-center.html" title="">Meta</a> broke ground on a $750 million data center on the edge of Newton County, Ga., the water taps in Beverly and Jeff Morris’s home went dry.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The couple’s house, which uses well water, is 1,000 feet from Meta’s new data center. Months after construction began in 2018, the Morrises’ dishwasher, ice maker, washing machine and toilet all stopped working, said Beverly Morris, now 71. Within a year, the water pressure had slowed to a trickle. Soon, nothing came out of the bathroom and kitchen taps.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="AudioBlock-1"><figure class="margins-h css-1nhp71k"><figcaption class="css-5soref"><div class="audioFigureHeading"><h3 class="css-71086k">Listen to this article with reporter commentary</h3></div></figcaption><div class="css-1ijhom3"><div><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"AudioObject","@id":"https://static.nytimes.com/podcasts/2025/07/16/business/rr-14biz-ai-water-audio/14biz-ai-water-FINAL-MIX-v2-KP.mp3","description":"","name":"Listen to this article with reporter commentary","contentUrl":"https://static.nytimes.com/podcasts/2025/07/16/business/rr-14biz-ai-water-audio/14biz-ai-water-FINAL-MIX-v2-KP.mp3","uploadDate":"2025-07-16T17:27:44.000Z","duration":"PT0.791S"}</script></div></div></figure></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-2"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-1"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Jeff Morris, 67, eventually traced the issues to the buildup of sediment in the water. He said he suspected the cause was Meta’s construction, which could have added sediment to the groundwater and affected their well. The couple replaced most of their appliances in 2019, and then again in 2021 and 2024. Residue now gathers at the bottom of their backyard pool. The taps in one of their two bathrooms still do not work.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="VideoBlock-4"><figure class="sizeMedium layoutVertical verticalVideo css-sx232s" aria-label="media" data-testid="VideoBlock"><div class="css-1xb94ky" style="position:relative"><span class="css-1dv1kvn">Video</span><div class="css-11kuxu4" style="width:100%;padding-bottom:177.77777777777777%;overflow:hidden"><div class="css-122y91a"><img src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/07/10/10visualUploader-89718-cover/10visualUploader-89718-cover-verticalTwoByThree735.jpg" class="css-gvnats" data-testid="cinemagraph_image"/><video data-testid="cinemagraph" poster="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/07/10/10visualUploader-89718-cover/10visualUploader-89718-cover-verticalTwoByThree735.jpg" src="https://vp.nyt.com/video/2025/07/10/144137_1_10visualUploader-89718_wg_1080p.mp4" class="cinemagraph_video css-gvnats" muted="" loop="" autoPlay="" playsInline=""></video></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-ktho12 e3rygrp0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0" data-testid="video-summary">Jeff and Beverly Morris.</span><span class="css-wgya1w"><span class="css-1dv1kvn">Credit</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span></span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-2"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It feels like we’re fighting an unwinnable battle that we didn’t sign up for,” said Ms. Morris, a retired payroll specialist, adding that she and her husband have spent $5,000 on their water problems and cannot afford the $25,000 to replace the well. “I’m scared to drink our own water.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The Morrises’ experience is one of a growing number of water-related issues around Newton County, which is a one-and-a-half-hour drive east of Atlanta and has a population of about 120,000 people. As tech giants like Meta build data centers in the area, local wells have been damaged, the cost of municipal water has soared and the county’s water commission may face a shortage of the vital resource.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The situation has become so dire that Newton County is on track to be in a water deficit by 2030, according to a report last year. If the local water authority cannot upgrade its facilities, residents could be forced to ration water. In the next two years, water rates are set to increase 33 percent, more than the typical 2 percent annual increases, said Blair Northen, the mayor of Mansfield, a town in Newton County.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Absolutely terrible,” he said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="DiptychBlock-6"><div class="css-zl9moh e73j0it0"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz- css-13wylk3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-fpbvhh ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Mr. Morris traced the home’s water issues to a buildup of sediment after Meta moved in.</span></figcaption></figure></div><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz- css-13wylk3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-fpbvhh ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">A collection of bottled water on the dining room table in the Morrises’ home.</span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-7"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-3"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/03/16/technology/ai-data-centers.html" title="">age of artificial intelligence</a>, water has become as critical to data centers — which power the development of the cutting-edge technology — as electricity. The facilities pump enormous amounts of cold water into pipes that run throughout the buildings to cool the computers inside so that they can perform calculations and keep internet services like social networking humming.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">A data center like Meta’s, which was completed last year, typically guzzles around 500,000 gallons of water a day. <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/24/technology/amazon-ai-data-centers.html" title="">New data centers</a> built to train more powerful A.I. are set to be even thirstier, requiring millions of gallons of water a day, according to water permit applications reviewed by The New York Times.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-9"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-full css-1kwayi3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/31/multimedia/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1800"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/31/multimedia/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/31/multimedia/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=600"/><img alt="Large buildings lit up with lights outside." class="css-r3fift" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/31/multimedia/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/31/multimedia/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/31/multimedia/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/05/31/multimedia/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf/DATACENTER-2-02-htbf-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 2048w" sizes="100vw" uri="nyt://image/0a9e897e-bc37-512d-811b-15903fba6cb8" decoding="async" width="600" height="400"/></picture></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-o5l7z4 ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Meta broke ground on the data center in Newton County in 2018. It was completed last year.</span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-4"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Data center companies often demand as much water as they can get, using the tax revenue they pay as leverage, said Newsha Ajami, a hydrologist and director of urban water policy at Stanford. Some projects are so large that they require the land to first be “dewatered,” which is when groundwater is pumped out of the surrounding area in preparation for construction.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Yet water is a particularly difficult resource to manage. If a municipality needs to add energy capacity to its grid, it can build new solar farms, wind turbines or reopen coal and nuclear power plants. But the water used by Newton County comes from a nearby reservoir that can be replenished with only rainwater.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-11"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-5"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Because <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/16/business/energy-environment/data-centers-utilities-electricity-bills.html" title="">electricity is more costly for data centers</a> than water, companies often prioritize building their facilities in places with cheap power, even if the area is drought stricken. That has exacerbated water shortages across the world, Ms. Ajami said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Water is an afterthought” for tech companies, she said. “The thinking is, ‘Someone will figure that out later.’”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-13"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-full css-1kwayi3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:290px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-o5l7z4 ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">A flood plain connects to a river near the Morris home. </span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-6"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Water troubles similar to Newton County’s are also playing out in other data center hot spots, including Texas, Arizona, Louisiana and the United Arab Emirates. Around Phoenix, some homebuilders have paused construction because of droughts exacerbated by data centers. In Colorado, water use by data centers has become a focal point of renegotiating the Colorado River’s water treaty.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">A Meta spokeswoman said the company had recently commissioned a well study on the Morrises’ property and said it was “unlikely” that its data center affected the supply of groundwater in the area.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-15"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-7"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Meta’s data center uses about 10 percent of the county’s total water use daily, said Mike Hopkins, the executive director of the Newton County Water and Sewerage Authority, which is the county’s water authority. The water authority has a good relationship with Meta, he said, but new data center companies are asking for more resources than close to what’s available.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“What the data centers don’t understand is that they’re taking up the community wealth,” he said. “We just don’t have the water.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">For years, Newton County was a growing residential exurb of Atlanta, until that future was put on hold by the 2008 financial crisis. Instead, local officials sought out large industrial projects to fill the void. In the late 2010s, data centers, which can generate millions of dollars in tax revenue, filled that bill.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Meta’s project was the first major data center to arrive in Georgia in 2018. At the time, Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, celebrated with <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10155436008516275&id=99033391274&set=a.381818291274" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Facebook-branded shovels</a> at the State Capitol. New tax incentives and cheap industrial power soon made Georgia one of the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.credaily.com/briefs/atlanta-tops-the-nation-for-2024-data-center-absorption/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">top picks in the nation for new data centers</a>.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In recent months, Mr. Hopkins said, nine companies had applied to build data centers in Newton County, some asking for as much as six million gallons of water a day — more than the county’s entire daily use. Some applicants are tech companies as large as Amazon, according to the water permits, while other companies used aliases to hide their identities.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-17"></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-18"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Ms. Morris has researched the effects of data centers on ground water.</span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-8"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The county’s water authority is wrestling with how to accommodate the projects — and the tax revenue they bring — while saving enough water for residents. Its solution is to upgrade its recycling facilities, which Mr. Hopkins said was a “race against the clock” that would cost more than $250 million.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Data center companies rarely disclose how much water they use, which has left some policymakers in the dark when it comes to regulation, said Chris Manganiello, the water policy director of Chattahoochee Riverkeeper, an environmental nonprofit in Georgia.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Last year, Mr. Manganiello figured out a way to get access to some data: If a site was so large it needed to rezone land, the company had to submit its water use as part of a mandatory regional development study.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The first time he saw the data, Mr. Manganiello said, his “eyes popped.” One data center company was asking for nine million gallons of water a day, equal to 30,000 households. “It is a tremendous amount,” he said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-20"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-9"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The strain on Georgia’s water has been so severe that some legislators tried to slow down new developments with a bill to repeal tax incentives. Those efforts were vetoed by Mr. Kemp, who said in a statement that the bill would hurt economic development.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">When Beverly and Jeff Morris bought their house in 2016, it was even quieter than their last home in Madison, Ga., a speck of a town with one stoplight. They paid $265,000 for the house and its six-acre lot, charmed by the dirt roads and forest of oak trees that Ms. Morris could ride her horses by.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It was supposed to be our forever home,” she said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-22"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Jon Barnett, the son of Beverly Morris from a previous marriage, opened presents for his 48th birthday. Mr. Barnett has Down syndrome.</span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-10"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Meta bulldozed the oak forest in 2019, and the well water problems began soon after. The couple have taken out thousands of dollars in loans to grapple with the water issues. Mr. Morris has also delayed his retirement as a machine operator at a nearby wood yard.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Three of their neighbors have also had issues with their well water since the data center was built. Chris Wilson, who lives three doors down, said his house had experienced water pressure issues within months of the construction. To keep the taps from going dry, he replaces the water filters every month instead of every year.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-24"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-11"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Sometimes the water is “so brown, you’d think it came from a creek,” Mr. Wilson, 40, said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Ben Sheidler, a spokesman for the Joint Development Authority, which manages the industrial park that Meta’s facilities occupy, said the cause of the water issues was unknown. The Joint Development Authority did not do a well water study before construction to determine any potential effects, but the timing of the problems could be a coincidence, he said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“I wouldn’t want to speculate that even the construction had something to do with it,” he said. “One thousand feet away is a pretty significant distance.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The hardest part, Ms. Morris said, is that the house now has just one usable bathroom, which they have to share with her adult son Jon, 48, who has Down syndrome. They tried selling the house, with no luck.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-26"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">The Morrises looking at the Meta data center from their front yard.</span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-12"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Our realtor told us, ‘There’s only one party that would ever be interested in buying this land — and that’s Facebook,’” she said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-28"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-13"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The walls of her home are decorated with phrases about faith and family, and she has spent countless nights questioning how the data center fits into God’s plan for her. Above the kitchen sink, one sign reads: “The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In May, after an activist media outlet, More Perfect Union, made a <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DGjj7wDYaiI" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">video</a> about some of the issues, Meta sent a community relations manager to visit. The company offered to do the well study and fixed some nighttime lighting to reduce glare, but it took no responsibility for the water issues.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">When Ms. Morris said she was afraid to cook with the tap water because of the sediment, the Meta employee suggested that she try boiling the water before using it. The company has denied that its employee said that.</p><div class="css-ms3zov"><div class="css-14jae4t"><div class="byline-container css-1e2jphy epjyd6m2"><div class="css-233int epjyd6m1"><p aria-labelledby="styln-guide-title" class="css-gtntm"><hr class="css-1vbto68 e1mu4ftr0"/><h2 id="styln-guide-title" class="css-mjvt74">Explore Our Coverage of Artificial Intelligence</h2><hr class="css-1jihs6t e1mu4ftr0"/><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">News</strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> and Analysis</strong></p><ul class="css-1gfen40 ez3869y0"><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Chip Sales to China:</strong> With help from a longtime Silicon Valley investor turned White House insider, <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/17/technology/nvidia-trump-ai-chips-china.html">Nvidia’s Jensen Huang</a> got the administration to <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/14/technology/nvidia-ai-chip-sales-china.html">reverse course on restrictions</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Energy Projects in Pennsylvania: </strong>President Trump visited Pittsburgh to <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/15/us/politics/trump-ai-pittsburgh-speech.html">praise companies for investing more than $90 billion in data centers and other projects</a> in the state, aimed at accelerating the development of artificial intelligence.</p></li><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Business Deals: </strong>Cognition AI, an artificial intelligence start-up that offers a software coding assistant, said that it had <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/14/technology/cognition-ai-windsurf.html">bought rival Windsurf</a> as part of an escalating battle to lead in the technology. The move follows a $2.4 billion deal by Google to <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/11/technology/google-windsurf-openai.html">acquire some of Windsurf’s top executives</a> and license the start-up’s technology</p></li><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Video Game Actors: </strong>After striking for nearly 11 months, actors <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/10/arts/video-game-actors-contract-ai.html">approved a new contract with major video game studios</a> that addressed concerns about the use of artificial intelligence to create digital replicas.</p></li></ul><hr class="css-1jihs6t e1mu4ftr0"/><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Age of A.I.</strong></p><ul class="css-1gfen40 ez3869y0"><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">The Rationalists:</strong> At first, Ziz LaSota seemed much like any other philosophically inclined young tech aspirant. Now, <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/06/business/ziz-lasota-zizians-rationalists.html">she and her followers are in jail, six people are dead</a>, and Rationalists are examining whether their ideas played a role.</p></li><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Mimicking the Mind: </strong>To better understand human cognition, scientists trained a large language model on 10 million psychology experiment questions. <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/02/science/ai-psychology-mind.html">It now answers questions much like we do</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Teaching Computer Science: </strong>Universities across the country are scrambling to understand the implications of <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/30/technology/computer-science-education-ai.html">generative A.I.’s transformation of technology</a>.</p></li><li class="css-1s64q9z eoqvrfo0"><p class="css-z7qbqf"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">Wearing Down Democracy</strong><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">:</strong> A.I. has long threatened to transform elections around the world. Now <a class="css-897g4k" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/26/technology/ai-elections-democracy.html">there is evidence from at least 50 countries that it already has</a>.</p></li></ul></section></div></div><div id="bottom-sheet-sensor"><section aria-labelledby="recirculation-title-placeholder" data-testid="recirculation-placeholder" class="css-s2htvn"><h2 tmlCaption":"Meta Some projects are so large that they require the land to first be “dewatered,” which is when groundwater is pumped out of the surrounding area in preparation for construction."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":12},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Yet water is a particularly difficult resource to manage. If a municipality needs to add energy capacity to its grid, it can build new solar farms, wind turbines or reopen coal and nuclear power plants. But the water used by Newton County comes from a nearby reservoir that can be replenished with only rainwater."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":13},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Because "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2025\u002F05\u002F16\u002Fbusiness\u002Fenergy-environment\u002Fdata-centers-utilities-electricity-bills.html"}],"text":"electricity is more costly for data centers"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" than water, companies often prioritize building their facilities in places with cheap power, even if the area is drought stricken. That has exacerbated water shortages across the world, Ms. Ajami said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":14},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“Water is an afterthought” for tech companies, she said. “The thinking is, ‘Someone will figure that out later.’”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":true,"index":15},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","media":{"__typename":"Image","altText":"An aerial view of a water source snaking through a heavily wooded area.","caption":{"__typename":"TextOnlyDocumentBlock","content":[{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"A flood plain connects to a river near the Morris home. ption":"A Around Phoenix, some homebuilders have paused construction because of droughts exacerbated by data centers. In Colorado, water use by data centers has become a focal point of renegotiating the Colorado River’s water treaty."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":17},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"A Meta spokeswoman said the company had recently commissioned a well study on the Morrises’ property and said it was “unlikely” that its data center affected the supply of groundwater in the area."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":18},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Meta’s data center uses about 10 percent of the county’s total water use daily, said Mike Hopkins, the executive director of the Newton County Water and Sewerage Authority, which is the county’s water authority. The water authority has a good relationship with Meta, he said, but new data center companies are asking for more resources than close to what’s available."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":19},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“What the data centers don’t understand is that they’re taking up the community wealth,” he said. “We just don’t have the water.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":20},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"For years, Newton County was a growing residential exurb of Atlanta, until that future was put on hold by the 2008 financial crisis. Instead, local officials sought out large industrial projects to fill the void. In the late 2010s, data centers, which can generate millions of dollars in tax revenue, filled that bill."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":21},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Meta’s project was the first major data center to arrive in Georgia in 2018. HtmlCaption":"Ms. county’s water authority is wrestling with how to accommodate the projects — and the tax revenue they bring — while saving enough water for residents. Its solution is to upgrade its recycling facilities, which Mr. Hopkins said was a “race against the clock” that would cost more than $250 million."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":25},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Data center companies rarely disclose how much water they use, which has left some policymakers in the dark when it comes to regulation, said Chris Manganiello, the water policy director of Chattahoochee Riverkeeper, an environmental nonprofit in Georgia."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":26},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Last study."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":27},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The first time he saw the data, Mr. Manganiello said, his “eyes popped.” One data center company was asking for nine million gallons of water a day, equal to 30,000 households. “It is a tremendous amount,” he said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":28},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The strain on Georgia’s water has been so severe that some legislators tried to slow down new developments with a bill to repeal tax incentives. Those efforts were vetoed by Mr. Kemp, who said in a statement that the bill would hurt economic development."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":29},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"When Beverly and Jeff Morris bought their house in 2016, it was even quieter than their last home in Madison, Ga., a speck of a town with one stoplight. They paid $265,000 for the house and its six-acre lot, charmed by the dirt roads and forest of oak trees that Ms. Morris could ride her horses by."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":30},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“It was supposed to be our forever home,” she said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","media":{"__typename":"Image","altText":"The Morris family around a table in a home with gift bags and banners saying “Happy Birthday.”","caption":{"__typename":"TextOnlyDocumentBlock","content":[{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Jon Barnett, the son of Beverly Morris from a previous marriage, opened presents for his 48th birthday. acyHtmlCaption":"Jon The couple have taken out thousands of dollars in loans to grapple with the water issues. Mr. Morris has also delayed his retirement as a machine operator at a nearby wood yard."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":32},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Three of their neighbors have also had issues with their well water since the data center was built. Chris Wilson, who lives three doors down, said his house had experienced water pressure issues within months of the construction. To keep the taps from going dry, he replaces the water filters every month instead of every year."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":33},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Sometimes the water is “so brown, you’d think it came from a creek,” Mr. Wilson, 40, said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Ben Sheidler, a spokesman for the Joint Development Authority, which manages the industrial park that Meta’s facilities occupy, said the cause of the water issues was unknown. The Joint Development Authority did not do a well water study before construction to determine any potential effects, but the timing of the problems could be a coincidence, he said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":34},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“I wouldn’t want to speculate that even the construction had something to do with it,” he said. “One thousand feet away is a pretty significant distance.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":35},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The hardest part, Ms. Morris said, is that the house now has just one usable bathroom, which they have to share with her adult son Jon, 48, who has Down syndrome. They tried selling the house, with no readabilityObject.title: Meta Built a Data Center Next Door. The Neighbors’ Water Taps Went Dry.
readabilityObject.content:
Their Water Taps Ran Dry When Meta Built Next Door

In the race to develop artificial intelligence, tech giants are building data centers that guzzle up water. That has led to problems for people who live nearby.

Meta’s data center in Newton County, Ga., is 1,000 feet from the home of Jeff and Beverly Morris.Credit...

  • Published July 14, 2025Updated July 16, 2025

After Meta broke ground on a $750 million data center on the edge of Newton County, Ga., the water taps in Beverly and Jeff Morris’s home went dry.

The couple’s house, which uses well water, is 1,000 feet from Meta’s new data center. Months after construction began in 2018, the Morrises’ dishwasher, ice maker, washing machine and toilet all stopped working, said Beverly Morris, now 71. Within a year, the water pressure had slowed to a trickle. Soon, nothing came out of the bathroom and kitchen taps.

Jeff Morris, 67, eventually traced the issues to the buildup of sediment in the water. He said he suspected the cause was Meta’s construction, which could have added sediment to the groundwater and affected their well. The couple replaced most of their appliances in 2019, and then again in 2021 and 2024. Residue now gathers at the bottom of their backyard pool. The taps in one of their two bathrooms still do not work.

“It feels like we’re fighting an unwinnable battle that we didn’t sign up for,” said Ms. Morris, a retired payroll specialist, adding that she and her husband have spent $5,000 on their water problems and cannot afford the $25,000 to replace the well. “I’m scared to drink our own water.”

The Morrises’ experience is one of a growing number of water-related issues around Newton County, which is a one-and-a-half-hour drive east of Atlanta and has a population of about 120,000 people. As tech giants like Meta build data centers in the area, local wells have been damaged, the cost of municipal water has soared and the county’s water commission may face a shortage of the vital resource.

The situation has become so dire that Newton County is on track to be in a water deficit by 2030, according to a report last year. If the local water authority cannot upgrade its facilities, residents could be forced to ration water. In the next two years, water rates are set to increase 33 percent, more than the typical 2 percent annual increases, said Blair Northen, the mayor of Mansfield, a town in Newton County.

“Absolutely terrible,” he said.

In the age of artificial intelligence, water has become as critical to data centers — which power the development of the cutting-edge technology — as electricity. The facilities pump enormous amounts of cold water into pipes that run throughout the buildings to cool the computers inside so that they can perform calculations and keep internet services like social networking humming.

A data center like Meta’s, which was completed last year, typically guzzles around 500,000 gallons of water a day. New data centers built to train more powerful A.I. are set to be even thirstier, requiring millions of gallons of water a day, according to water permit applications reviewed by The New York Times.

Data center companies often demand as much water as they can get, using the tax revenue they pay as leverage, said Newsha Ajami, a hydrologist and director of urban water policy at Stanford. Some projects are so large that they require the land to first be “dewatered,” which is when groundwater is pumped out of the surrounding area in preparation for construction.

Yet water is a particularly difficult resource to manage. If a municipality needs to add energy capacity to its grid, it can build new solar farms, wind turbines or reopen coal and nuclear power plants. But the water used by Newton County comes from a nearby reservoir that can be replenished with only rainwater.

Because electricity is more costly for data centers than water, companies often prioritize building their facilities in places with cheap power, even if the area is drought stricken. That has exacerbated water shortages across the world, Ms. Ajami said.

“Water is an afterthought” for tech companies, she said. “The thinking is, ‘Someone will figure that out later.’”

Water troubles similar to Newton County’s are also playing out in other data center hot spots, including Texas, Arizona, Louisiana and the United Arab Emirates. Around Phoenix, some homebuilders have paused construction because of droughts exacerbated by data centers. In Colorado, water use by data centers has become a focal point of renegotiating the Colorado River’s water treaty.

A Meta spokeswoman said the company had recently commissioned a well study on the Morrises’ property and said it was “unlikely” that its data center affected the supply of groundwater in the area.

Meta’s data center uses about 10 percent of the county’s total water use daily, said Mike Hopkins, the executive director of the Newton County Water and Sewerage Authority, which is the county’s water authority. The water authority has a good relationship with Meta, he said, but new data center companies are asking for more resources than close to what’s available.

“What the data centers don’t understand is that they’re taking up the community wealth,” he said. “We just don’t have the water.”

For years, Newton County was a growing residential exurb of Atlanta, until that future was put on hold by the 2008 financial crisis. Instead, local officials sought out large industrial projects to fill the void. In the late 2010s, data centers, which can generate millions of dollars in tax revenue, filled that bill.

Meta’s project was the first major data center to arrive in Georgia in 2018. At the time, Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, celebrated with Facebook-branded shovels at the State Capitol. New tax incentives and cheap industrial power soon made Georgia one of the top picks in the nation for new data centers.

In recent months, Mr. Hopkins said, nine companies had applied to build data centers in Newton County, some asking for as much as six million gallons of water a day — more than the county’s entire daily use. Some applicants are tech companies as large as Amazon, according to the water permits, while other companies used aliases to hide their identities.

The county’s water authority is wrestling with how to accommodate the projects — and the tax revenue they bring — while saving enough water for residents. Its solution is to upgrade its recycling facilities, which Mr. Hopkins said was a “race against the clock” that would cost more than $250 million.

Data center companies rarely disclose how much water they use, which has left some policymakers in the dark when it comes to regulation, said Chris Manganiello, the water policy director of Chattahoochee Riverkeeper, an environmental nonprofit in Georgia.

Last year, Mr. Manganiello figured out a way to get access to some data: If a site was so large it needed to rezone land, the company had to submit its water use as part of a mandatory regional development study.

The first time he saw the data, Mr. Manganiello said, his “eyes popped.” One data center company was asking for nine million gallons of water a day, equal to 30,000 households. “It is a tremendous amount,” he said.

The strain on Georgia’s water has been so severe that some legislators tried to slow down new developments with a bill to repeal tax incentives. Those efforts were vetoed by Mr. Kemp, who said in a statement that the bill would hurt economic development.

When Beverly and Jeff Morris bought their house in 2016, it was even quieter than their last home in Madison, Ga., a speck of a town with one stoplight. They paid $265,000 for the house and its six-acre lot, charmed by the dirt roads and forest of oak trees that Ms. Morris could ride her horses by.

“It was supposed to be our forever home,” she said.

Meta bulldozed the oak forest in 2019, and the well water problems began soon after. The couple have taken out thousands of dollars in loans to grapple with the water issues. Mr. Morris has also delayed his retirement as a machine operator at a nearby wood yard.

Three of their neighbors have also had issues with their well water since the data center was built. Chris Wilson, who lives three doors down, said his house had experienced water pressure issues within months of the construction. To keep the taps from going dry, he replaces the water filters every month instead of every year.

Sometimes the water is “so brown, you’d think it came from a creek,” Mr. Wilson, 40, said.

Ben Sheidler, a spokesman for the Joint Development Authority, which manages the industrial park that Meta’s facilities occupy, said the cause of the water issues was unknown. The Joint Development Authority did not do a well water study before construction to determine any potential effects, but the timing of the problems could be a coincidence, he said.

“I wouldn’t want to speculate that even the construction had something to do with it,” he said. “One thousand feet away is a pretty significant distance.”

The hardest part, Ms. Morris said, is that the house now has just one usable bathroom, which they have to share with her adult son Jon, 48, who has Down syndrome. They tried selling the house, with no luck.

“Our realtor told us, ‘There’s only one party that would ever be interested in buying this land — and that’s Facebook,’” she said.

The walls of her home are decorated with phrases about faith and family, and she has spent countless nights questioning how the data center fits into God’s plan for her. Above the kitchen sink, one sign reads: “The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh.”

In May, after an activist media outlet, More Perfect Union, made a video about some of the issues, Meta sent a community relations manager to visit. The company offered to do the well study and fixed some nighttime lighting to reduce glare, but it took no responsibility for the water issues.

When Ms. Morris said she was afraid to cook with the tap water because of the sediment, the Meta employee suggested that she try boiling the water before using it. The company has denied that its employee said that.

Audio produced by Sarah Diamond.

Eli Tan covers the technology industry for The Times from San Francisco.

A version of this article appears in print on  , Section

A

, Page

1

of the New York edition

with the headline:

As Meta Built, Neighbors Saw Faucets Dry Up. Order Reprints | Today’s Paper | Subscribe
